comprehensive.question: Trace the rise of the Marathas from their origins as Deccan Sultanate soldiers through their unique revenue model to the founding of the Maratha Empire under Shivaji.
comprehensive.answer: Origins: Marathas were originally soldiers for Deccan Sultanates - military service background. Not Mughal officials or independent from start. Rise to Power: Grew powerful by leveraging Maharashtra's wealth. Transitioned from mercenary soldiers to independent power base using regional economic resources. Unique Revenue Model: Imposed Chauth (25%) and Sardeshmukhi (10%) taxes on Mughal lands. Significance: 1) Operated revenue collection on Mughal territory without Mughal authority, 2) 35% total extraction (Chauth 25% + Sardeshmukhi 10%) was substantial burden, 3) Unique system different from Mughal jagirdari or zamindari - direct Maratha imposition on imperial lands demonstrated Maratha power. Foundation of Empire: Shivaji founded the Maratha Empire. Formalized Maratha independence and state structure. Pattern: Mercenary soldiers (Deccan Sultanates) → Independent power (Maharashtra wealth) → Revenue extraction (Chauth/Sardeshmukhi on Mughal lands) → Empire formation (Shivaji). Significance as 'The New States': Marathas exemplify rebellious state formation - rose against/outside existing systems (Deccan Sultanates, Mughals) rather than from within Mughal administration like Successor States. Revenue model (taxing Mughal lands) showed they operated as independent power even before formal empire.

comprehensive.question: Analyze the consolidation and expansion of Maratha power from Sambhaji through Shahu, Balaji Vishwanath, and Baji Rao I.
comprehensive.answer: Sambhaji (Post-Shivaji): Continued resistance against Aurangzeb after Shivaji's death. Maintained Maratha independence during peak Mughal pressure under Aurangzeb. Defensive consolidation preserving Shivaji's legacy. Shahu (Post-Captivity): Secured Maratha influence after his release from Mughal captivity. Background: Had been held captive by Mughals, creating succession uncertainty. Achievement: Established legitimacy and secured influence despite captivity background - political consolidation. Balaji Vishwanath (Peshwa): As Peshwa (prime minister), consolidated Maratha territories. Peshwa Institution: Shift from monarchical to administrative leadership - Peshwas became key power centers in Maratha confederacy. Territorial consolidation: Brought fragmented Maratha holdings under unified administration. Baji Rao I (Expansion): Expanded Maratha reach even to Agra - deep into Mughal heartland in north. Military and territorial expansion at empire's peak. Significance: From defensive resistance (Sambhaji vs Aurangzeb) → Political consolidation (Shahu post-captivity) → Administrative consolidation (Balaji Vishwanath as Peshwa) → Territorial expansion (Baji Rao I to Agra). Each phase built on previous: Sambhaji preserved independence, Shahu secured leadership, Balaji Vishwanath consolidated administration, Baji Rao I expanded territory. Peshwa emergence (Balaji Vishwanath) particularly significant - created powerful ministerial position that would dominate later Maratha politics.

comprehensive.question: Examine the Third Battle of Panipat (1761) and its impact on Maratha power, comparing with their earlier expansion under Baji Rao I.
comprehensive.answer: Peak Under Baji Rao I: Expanded Maratha reach even to Agra - controlled/influenced territory deep in north, Mughal heartland. Represented zenith of Maratha territorial expansion. Third Battle of Panipat (1761): Against Ahmad Shah Abdali (Afghan invader). Resulted in significant Maratha defeat. Impact: Led to weakening of Maratha power - reversed expansion trajectory. Context: This was same Ahmad Shah Abdali who captured Delhi (1757) and defeated Marathas at Panipat (1761) - part of his multiple invasions weakening both Mughals and regional powers. Significance of Defeat: 1) Military: Massive casualties weakened Maratha military capacity, 2) Political: Loss of northern territories/influence gained under Baji Rao I, 3) Psychological: Shattered image of Maratha invincibility, 4) Strategic: Created power vacuum in north that British would later exploit. Comparison - Expansion vs Decline: Baji Rao I: Expansion to Agra (northward, into Mughal core). Third Battle of Panipat: Defeat at Panipat (same northern region, but withdrawal/defeat). Timeframe: Less than 30 years between Baji Rao I's peak expansion and Panipat defeat (1761). Rapid reversal. Pattern: Marathas rose from Deccan Sultanate soldiers → Founded empire (Shivaji) → Consolidated (Peshwas) → Expanded to peak (Baji Rao I to Agra) → Defeated (Third Panipat 1761) → Weakened. Third Battle of Panipat marked turning point where Marathas shifted from expansion to defense, ultimately unable to fill Mughal power vacuum, leaving opportunity for British expansion.
